column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Stargaze Without a Telescope
#Text=Not everyone has , or wants to use , a telescope for stargazing .
#Text=It 's still fine to watch the stars as the ancients did it , by simply looking up and recognizing familiar constellations .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Decide what you want to look at .
#Text=You may have heard about it from a friend , or read about it , or found it on the internet .
#Text=Check if the constellation or star is bright enough .
#Text=For this , you need to know your target 's magnitude .
#Text=Bigger magnitude = dimmer object .
#Text=To see if it 's bright enough , identify the five dimmest stars in the sky that you can see without straining your eyes .
#Text=Take an average of their magnitudes .
#Text=If the magnitude of your target is less than this average value , then you will be able to see it .
#Text=Anything with a magnitude of less than 1.5 , you will definitely be able to see , unless you have extreme light pollution .
#Text=Anything more than about 6 cannot be seen from anywhere except under exceptional circumstances .
#Text=Find the star or constellation on a star map .
#Text=You need to know where it is to be able to see it .
#Text=Also find a few signposts - bright objects that you can use to locate your target .
#Text=For example , Orion 's belt is a signpost to a star called Procyon .
#Text=Star maps can be accessed online , or can be bought from decent bookstores .
#Text=Use stargazing app on mobile phones .
#Text=Apps are very helpful to search for what is in the night sky with the timing .
#Text=Most of the app provided are Paid .
#Text=One of the best app is Stellarium[ https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.noctuasoftware.stellarium&hl=en ]
#Text=Wrap up and keep warm .
#Text=It can get very cold outside at night , even in summer .
#Text=Take a deckchair or recliner with you .
#Text=You 're going to be looking up at the sky , so if you can orient yourself so that you are facing the sky without bending your neck , it can help avoid a stiff neck .
#Text=Alternatively , you can get a stiff neck and take two aspirin when you get back inside .
#Text=Get to a place where you can see your target .
#Text=This may be your back garden , your roof , or a dark site way out in the countryside .
#Text=You can get the best views from dark sites , but they can be a bit tricky to get to .
#Text=Wait for ten minutes so that you can see better .
#Text=Do n't look at any light sources or it will ruin your night vision .
#Text=Use your signposts to locate your target .
#Text=Enjoy !
#Text=Tips
#Text=It is recommended that you choose four or five targets for one night , so you can move on to another after you get bored .
#Text=Stargazing with naked eyes need lot of patience so give yourself time before fed up .
#Text=Search the internet to know in which class your city falls in context of light pollution
#Text=this will help you know which celestial bodies will be easily seen with naked eyes .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Astronomical observations always look better in photos than in reality .
#Text=Ever seen that cool photo of the Andromeda galaxy ?
#Text=Know what it looks like without a telescope ?
#Text=A little grey fuzzy patch , that 's what .
#Text=Never look at the Sun .
#Text=It will burn your eyes out .
